title: Fair Division with Subsidy
description: Fair division of $m$ indivisible goods among $n$ agents with additive valuations, where each good has value at most 1 to each agent.
results: Section 2: A slightly different definition of the envy graph of an allocation.

Theorem 1: For any allocation $A$, the following are equivalent: (i) $A$ is envy-freeable, (ii) $A$ is welfare maximizing across all reassignments of its bundles to agents, (iii) $G_A$ has no positive-weight cycles.

Theorem 2: For any envy-freeable allocation $A$, let $p^*_i$ be the max weight of any path starting at $i$ in $A$'s envy graph. Then $(A, p^*)$ is EF. Moreover, $p^*$ can be computed in $O(nm + n^3)$ time, and for any $p$ such that $(A, p)$ is EF, $p^*_i ≤ p_i$ for all $i$. (Call $p^*$ the minimum subsidy vector for $A$.)
Theorem 3: Let $A$ be an envy-freeable allocation. Then the minimum total subsidy is at most $(n-1)m$. This is tight: $m$ identical goods of value 1, all of which are allocated to a single agent.
Theorem 4: For any fair division instance, the minimum total subsidy is at least $n-1$ (single good of value 1).
Lemma 2: For any EF1 allocation $A$, the minimum total subsidy is $≤ (n-1)\min(n-1, m)$.
Theorem 5: For binary valuations, the max-Nash-welfare allocation is EF1 and its minimum total subsidy is $≤ n-1$.
Proposition 4: When valuations are identical, for any EF1 allocation $A$, the minimum total subsidy is $≤ (n-1)$.
Theorem 6: When $n=2$, there is an agent ordering such that the allocation returned by round-robin is envy-freeable and requires $≤ 1$ subsidy.
